stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the overworld for 'Return to Yoshi's Island,' focusing on redesigning a large, uninteresting beach area to connect multiple level entrances. The stream is significantly interrupted by a technical issue where Kaze must troubleshoot his full hard drive, revealing his frustrations with system maintenance. He discusses design philosophy and future plans before ending early due to illness.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is building a new, expansive single-level overworld from scratch because he felt the previous version did not meet the project's quality standards.
development_findings.quote: The original overworld is completely erased. It's just not up to the quality standards.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified a key design problem with the overworld's central hub: a large, flat beach area that was visually boring and unengaging to traverse.
development_findings.quote: This beach is depressing and sad. I can't leave it like this, I need to do something.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has implemented a custom step function in his engine that improves on the original Mario 64 physics, specifically eliminating the issue of players getting stuck on thin invisible walls.
development_findings.quote: My game uses a whole different step function that works very differently from Mario 64's. And hitting an invisible wall just doesn't happen anymore with that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze strongly criticizes the original Mario 64 source code, stating it made development harder and serves as a counterexample to the idea that older programming was superior.
development_findings.quote: The Mario 64 engine is just the worst. Whenever someone tells you that programmers used to be better back in the day, just show them the Mario 64 engine code.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimated that the project is currently 'maybe like 10% done,' indicating it is still in the early stages of development.
He plans to seek out playtesters for Course 11 to gather valuable feedback and data.
In response to a question about selling cartridges, Kaze sarcastically dismissed the idea and confirmed he would not do so due to legal issues with Nintendo.
development_findings.quote: I'm sure I can buy it any day now, I'm still saving up though.

development_findings.summary: He briefly showcased Course 6, 'Jurassic Jungle,' which features prehistoric Yoshis, but noted it currently has a bug preventing a full demonstration.
Ideas for making the overworld more interesting include a sandcastle-based obstacle course for a blue coin and an NPC quest to help retrieve something from the ocean.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a clear preference for creating new systems (game development) over maintaining existing ones (PC troubleshooting), highlighting a core part of his creative identity.
context_findings.quote: With computers you're just learning about things someone else made. You have to deal with someone else's systems. It's not like you're making new systems, you know. That's what I do.

context_findings.summary: Kaze laments the state of the modern game industry, advocating for smaller, riskier, and more creative projects over safe, big-budget titles.
context_findings.quote: Let's start making based games again, simpler games, not just the 'Hey, let's throw six million dollars at it and make something very safe that is guaranteed to not be garbage' type games. We'd be making risky games again.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed he suffered a significant data loss from a broken SSD, losing undocumented old code and project history that was not backed up.
context_findings.quote: My old SSD broke and I lost a little bit of work to that. And a lot of documentation, which kind of sucks. It had a lot of old hack code that I never uploaded to GitHub. So all that is gone, which sucks.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explicitly states that he is pursuing sponsorships for his YouTube content to support his family, indicating a direct financial pressure influencing his work.
context_findings.quote: I gotta make money for my family.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared his personal philosophy on parenting, believing in being more transparent with children about difficult topics.
context_findings.quote: I think children are a lot more emotionally ready to hear uncomfortable truths than we give them credit for.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is feeling very sick and feverish throughout the stream, which negatively impacts his mood and stamina, causing him to end the stream early.
Kaze reveals that his attempt to monetize his presence on Twitter was unsuccessful, highlighting a failed revenue-seeking experiment.
context_findings.quote: I had hoped that I could make a little bit of money posting on Twitter. And that just did not happen. Like at all.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time feedback in chat, pointing out a symmetry issue in a room in Course 2, which Kaze immediately acknowledged and confirmed was a mistake he made.
biobak.quote: Did I do did I make them not square by a back what's wrong? ... I guess it's in the disco area. And of course to then I fuck up the symmetry. Yeah, oh shit.

zeina.summary: Kaze reviewed a concept drawing by Zeina for a cave entrance but decided it didn't fit his vision for the level, showing their collaborative but distinct creative process.
zeina.quote: Let's see if we can find Zeina's drawings here real quick. This is what Zeina had, doesn't really work, I do want it to be a cave.

zeina.summary: Kaze shared a lighthearted personal anecdote about creating a song that Zeina dislikes, offering a brief glimpse into their personal relationship dynamic.
zeina.quote: Can we all do a deal the next time you see Zaina tell her that the wasabi song is actually like really good. I invented the wasabi song in the car today, and she won't believe it's good.

key_stories.title: The Disk Space Crisis
key_stories.summary: Kaze's development progress was halted by a full hard drive, forcing a frustrating detour into PC maintenance. With help from his viewers, he managed to clear enough space to resume work, highlighting the fragile technical dependencies of even a creative workflow.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze was unable to open a large Photoshop file essential for his work because his main hard drive was completely full.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream troubleshooting the disk space issue. He deleted old programs and cache files, used WinDirStat to identify large folders, and attempted to run command-line tools, all while expressing his frustration with computer maintenance.
key_stories.outcome: After a lengthy process of deleting files and running system utilities with help from his chat, he freed up enough space to open the file and continue working. The incident prompted him to resolve to install a new, larger SSD he already owned.
key_stories.key_quote: My actual hard drive is so full that I can't open Photoshop? What the fuck? What do I even do at this point?

key_stories.title: Redeeming the Depressing Beach
key_stories.summary: Faced with a creatively bankrupt area in his overworld, Kaze used the stream as a brainstorming session to solve the design problem. He transformed a boring, flat beach into a planned space with more verticality and purpose, demonstrating his iterative design process.
key_stories.challenge: The central hub of the game's overworld was a large, flat, and visually uninteresting beach that Kaze found 'depressing and sad'.
key_stories.process: Kaze verbally processed the design problem and brainstormed solutions live on stream. He considered adding sand dunes and other natural features before settling on the idea of man-made wooden foundations, which serve to break up the landscape and provide environmental storytelling.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a concrete plan to improve the area by adding verticality with wooden platforms ('floor plan notes') and brainstorming interactive elements like a sandcastle obstacle course, turning a design problem into a clear set of actionable tasks.
key_stories.key_quote: This beach is depressing and sad. I can't leave it like this, I need to do something.

key_stories.title: The F3 Rejection Story
key_stories.summary: Kaze recounted a story from his past where he rejected an over-ambitious but underdeveloped project from a community showcase. The incident highlights his experience and pragmatism in managing community standards and dealing with passionate but unrealistic creators.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze recalled his role as a gatekeeper for a past SM64 hacking community event (F3) and the need to reject a project that was not viable.
key_stories.process: Kaze explained that a modder submitted a 'Super Mario Galaxy 64' project with only a title screen and T-posing Mario. Kaze made the decision to reject it to maintain the showcase's quality standard, despite the creator's angry reaction and promise to finish the game.
key_stories.outcome: The angry modder's project was ultimately abandoned, validating Kaze's judgment call. The story serves as an example of his long-standing, pragmatic leadership role within the modding community.
key_stories.key_quote: And I rejected him with the reasoning that it's like, okay, you have one week of progress done and this is probably never gonna get finished, so I'm not letting you in.

open_questions.topic: Lost SSD Data and Project Preservation
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that a previous SSD had failed, causing him to lose 'a lot of documentation' and 'old hack code that I never uploaded to GitHub.'
questions: You mentioned losing significant work from a past SSD failure. Can you describe what the most painful loss was from that event?
How did losing that undocumented history of your work affect you emotionally?
Has that experience changed how you approach data preservation and backing up your projects now?

open_questions.topic: Critique of the Original Mario 64 Engine
open_questions.context: Kaze praised the work of original SM64 programmer Giles Goddard while strongly criticizing the code written by the rest of the team, calling the engine 'the worst'.
questions: When you look at the Mario 64 source code, what are the specific qualities of Giles Goddard's work that make it stand out as superior?
Can you give an example of a system in the original game that was particularly poorly implemented and made your work harder?
How has this deep understanding of the original game's technical flaws and strengths influenced your own design and programming philosophy for this project?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that he looked at a concept drawing by Zeina for a cave but decided it 'doesn't really work' with his vision.
questions: Could you walk us through the collaborative process between you and Zeina? How do ideas flow back and forth?
What was the specific feedback on the cave drawing? How do you two navigate creative disagreements?
How does your dynamic as partners translate into your working relationship on a major creative project?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated he needs to get more sponsors to 'make money for my family' and mentioned a past attempt to monetize Twitter failed.
questions: How do you balance the time and energy spent creating sponsored content versus working on a passion project like this?
Does the pressure to generate income through your content ever affect the creative direction or pace of the game's development?
What are your criteria for choosing a sponsor to partner with?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions in passing that 'The Drug Wars game is done almost too.'
questions: You briefly mentioned another project called 'Drug Wars.' What is that game and how does it fit into your creative life alongside Yoshi's Island?
